name: Basil
description: culinary herb of the family Lamiaceae (mints). Basil is native to tropical regions from central Africa to Southeast Asia
usage: Best with tomato sauce and served with different vegetables

name: Curry
description: variety of dishes originating in the Indian subcontinent, dating back to the Indus Valley Civilisation, that use a complex combination of spices or herbs, usually including ground turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger, and fresh or dried chilies

name: Rosemary
country: not specified exactly, but it comes from south of France and other Mediterranean regions
description: is a woody, perennial herb with fragrant, evergreen, needle-like leaves and white, pink, purple, or blue flowers, native to the Mediterranean region.
usage: Best with pork and grilled potatos

name: Sage
country: not specified exactly, but is somewhere from Mediterranean region
description: perennial, evergreen subshrub, with woody stems, grayish leaves, and blue to purplish flowers. It is a member of the mint family Lamiaceae and native to the Mediterranean region, though it has naturalized in many places throughout the world.
usage: Best with butter and baked potatos

name: Oregano
description: flowering plant in the mint family. It is native to temperate Western and Southwestern Eurasia and the Mediterranean region. Oregano is a perennial herb, growing from 20–80 cm tall, with opposite leaves 1–4 cm long
usage: Best with every meal, especially meat and potatos

name: Thyme
description: contains about 350 species of aromatic perennial herbaceous plants and subshrubs to 40 cm tall in the family Lamiaceae, native to temperate regions in Europe, North Africa and Asia
usage: Best with red meat and fish

name: Chive
description: very popular garnishing spice in French and Chinese cooking. The name “chives” is derived from the Latin word cepa, meaning onion, which later became cive in French. Called little onion in European languages, they are related to onion, leek, and garlic and used as spice or vegetable, depending on the region. Chives are native to Central Asia and now cultivated in Scandinavia, Germany, Britain, China, and Southeast Asia.
usage: Best with soups, stew and various risottos

name: Ginger
country: not specified, but somewhere in Southeast Asia
description: flowering plant whose rhizome, ginger root or ginger, is widely used as a spice and a folk medicine. It is a herbaceous perennial which grows annual pseudostems about one meter tall bearing narrow leaf blades
usage: Best with salamon, in various souces togetehr with soja souce

name: Cumin
country: not specified, but somewhere in Asia
description: flowering plant in the family Apiaceae, native to southwestern Asia including the Middle East. Its seeds – each one contained within a fruit, which is dried – are used in the cuisines of many cultures in both whole and ground form
usage: Best with bread and baked potatos

name: Clove
country: not specified, but maybe from Madagascar, Indonesia and Sri Lanka
description: aromatic flower buds of a tree in the family Myrtaceae, Syzygium aromaticum. They are native to the Maluku Islands in Indonesia, and are commonly used as a spice. Cloves are available throughout the year due to different harvest seasons in different countries
usage: Best with cookies and mulled wien

name: StarAnis
country: not specified, but maybe from China
description: medium-sized evergreen tree native to northeast Vietnam and southwest China. A spice commonly called star anise, staranise, star anise seed, Chinese star anise, or badian that closely resembles anise in flavor is obtained from the star-shaped pericarps of the fruit of I. verum which are harvested just before ripening. Star anise oil is a highly fragrant oil used in cooking, perfumery, soaps, toothpastes, mouthwashes, and skin creams. About 90% of the world's star anise crop is used for extraction of shikimic acid, a chemical intermediate used in the synthesis of oseltamivir (Tamiflu)
usage: Best with cookies and other sweets, as well as in mulled wine
